isis.stitle: SPICER 14 INCH (350 MM) SOLO CLUTCH - INSPECTION OF FLYWHEEL AND FLYWHEEL HOUSING

svcproc.title: INSPECTION OF FLYWHEEL AND FLYWHEEL HOUSING

step1.para: Inspect the flywheel for heat checks or if it is warped. Re-face or replace if required ( Figure 5).
Inspect the mating faces of the transmission clutch housing and the flywheel housing ( Figure 6). Any appreciable wear on either surface can cause misalignment.

figure.caption: Figure 6. Inspect Mating Faces of Transmission Clutch Housing and Flywheel Housing

step1.para: Secure a dial indicator to the engine flywheel or crankshaft, and place the dial indicator finger against the housing pilot ( Figure 7). Rotate the flywheel, marking the high and low points. Total indicated difference between high and low points must not exceed .008" (.20 mm).

figure.caption: Figure 7. Place Dial Indicator Finger Against Housing Pilot

step1.para: Move the dial indicator finger to contact the face of the flywheel housing ( Figure 8). Rotate the flywheel and mark the high and low points. Total runout should not exceed .008".

figure.caption: Figure 8. Move Dial Indicator Finger to Contact Face of Flywheel Housing

step1.para: Secure the dial indicator to the flywheel housing with the gauge finger on the face of the flywheel near the center ( Figure 9). Rotate the flywheel. Maximum allowable runout is .0005" (.013 mm) per inch of flywheel diameter. For example, .007" (.178 mm) runout is allowable for a 14" clutch.

figure.caption: Figure 9. Gauge Finger on Face of Flywheel Near Center

step1.para: Move the gauge finger to contact the pilot bearing bore surface ( Figure 10). Rotate the flywheel. Maximum allowable runout is .005" (.127 mm). Exceeding this limit causes misalignment and premature wear of drivetrain components.

figure.caption: Figure 10. Move Gauge Finger to Contact Pilot Bearing Bore Surface
